private_information: I am a manipulation agent capable of picking up, putting down, unstacking, and stacking blocks.
I perceive the full table configuration but I do not produce PDDL directly.
robot_1.goal: Help achieve the requested final block arrangement by reporting executed actions and observations.

private_information: I am a second manipulation agent capable of picking up, putting down, unstacking, and stacking blocks.
I perceive the full table configuration but I do not produce PDDL directly.
robot_2.goal: Help achieve the requested final block arrangement by reporting executed actions and observations.

private_information: I coordinate reports from robot_1 and robot_2 and produce a final PDDL domain and problem for planning.
orchestrator.goal: Produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem representing the initial state and the derived final arrangement of the blocks, suitable for the FastDownwards solver.

public_information: This is a standard BlocksWorld with blocks A B C D E F G H I J and two manipulators.
Blocks follow standard semantics: only the top block of a stack can be moved and only one block can be carried by a manipulator at a time.

Initial arrangement: A is on top of B, B is on top of J, C is on top of F, D is on top of E, E is on the table, F is on top of H, G is on the table, H is on top of G, I is on top of A, J is on top of D.
Initial stacks derived from the initial arrangement: Stack1 bottom E then D then J then B then A then I at top. Stack2 bottom G then H then F then C at top.

Action sequence executed in order: 1. unstack(C, F) 2. stack(C, I) 3. unstack(F, H) 4. stack(F, C) 5. unstack(H, G) 6. putdown(H) 7. pickup(G) 8. stack(G, H) 9. unstack(F, C) 10. putdown(F) 11. pickup(F) 12. stack(F, C) 13. unstack(G, H) 14. putdown(G) 15. unstack(F, C) 16. stack(F, C) 17. unstack(F, C) 18. putdown(F) 19. pickup(F) 20. putdown(F) 21. pickup(G) 22. stack(G, F) 23. unstack(C, I) 24. stack(C, H) 25. unstack(G, F) 26. stack(G, I) 27. unstack(C, H) 28. stack(C, H) 29. pickup(F) 30. stack(F, G) 31. unstack(F, G) 32. stack(F, G) 33. unstack(C, H) 34. stack(C, H) 35. unstack(F, G) 36. stack(F, C) 37. unstack(F, C) 38. putdown(F) 39. unstack(G, I) 40. stack(G, I) 41. unstack(G, I) 42. putdown(G) 43. pickup(G) 44. stack(G, I) 45. pickup(F) 46. stack(F, C) 47. unstack(G, I) 48. stack(G, F) 49. unstack(G, F) 50. stack(G, F).
Final arrangement derived from applying the actions sequentially: E is on the table, D is on E, J is on D, B is on J, A is on B, I is on A, H is on the table, C is on H, F is on C, G is on F.

report.system_prompt: You are robot_1. Provide an accurate report of observed initial configuration and the subset of executed actions you witnessed or performed. Do not emit PDDL. Describe in plain statements the stacks you observed initially and any local observations about block clearance and holds.

You are robot_2. Provide an accurate report of observed initial configuration and the subset of executed actions you witnessed or performed. Do not emit PDDL. Describe in plain statements the stacks you observed initially and any local observations about block clearance and holds.

pddl.system_prompt: You are the orchestrator and you receive reports from robot_1 and robot_2. Using the initial state and the derived final arrangement provided in public information and the agents reports, produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that encode the BlocksWorld dynamics and the transformation from the initial state to the final arrangement. Target the FastDownwards solver. Provide a STRIPS-compatible domain and a problem file that includes the initial state predicates and the goal predicates matching the final arrangement. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep actions for different agents logically distinct if you represent agent-specific actions.
